haefeleuser wrote:

> Do we do too much testing here? How do you test these things? Or don't
> you test them or only some of them? Is there any code example of such
> a test? What about the finders and the validation rules: Do you test them?

DAOs are merely a facade to the persistence mechanism. As such, they 
only map data types and construct SQL statements, if that. Test that: 
does the DAO properly look up the right EJB in JNDI? I recommend having 
a constructor for each DAO that accepts a Context which you can fake 
out. In the fake context, put a mock entity bean component interface and 
tell it to expect the right method name with the right parameters.

Since the persistence mechanism is CMP EJB, test the entity beans 
themselves in the container only to the extent you're paranoid about CMP 
not working. I don't recommend trying to test your bean class with 
fake/mock CMP interfaces. That's painful. You could write some tests to 
verify the CMP metadata by merely parsing the deployment descriptors.

This is mostly covered in Chapters 10 and 11 of _JUnit Recipes_.
